questions.question: When installing Docker on a Linux VM, why is it recommended to add your user to the 'docker' group rather than running Docker commands with sudo?
options: It improves container performance by reducing system overhead
It prevents security vulnerabilities and follows the principle of least privilege
It allows multiple users to run containers simultaneously
It enables automatic container startup on system boot
questions.explanation: Adding users to the docker group eliminates the need for sudo with every Docker command while maintaining proper access control. Running Docker with sudo can create security risks and file permission issues.

questions.question: A developer wants to run Docker containers on their MacBook for local development. What is the primary reason Docker Desktop uses a lightweight Linux VM on macOS?
options: To improve container performance compared to native execution
Because Docker containers share the host OS kernel, which must be Linux
To provide better isolation between containers and the host system
To enable compatibility with Windows containers
questions.explanation: Docker containers are built on Linux kernel features like namespaces and cgroups. Since macOS doesn't have a Linux kernel, Docker Desktop runs a lightweight Linux VM to provide the necessary kernel environment.

questions.question: During Docker installation verification, what does the command 'docker run hello-world' primarily test?
options: Whether the Docker daemon can communicate with Docker Hub and run containers
If the Docker networking configuration is properly set up
Whether sufficient disk space is available for container storage
If the Docker CLI tools are correctly installed
questions.explanation: The hello-world container tests the complete Docker workflow: pulling an image from Docker Hub, creating a container, running it, and displaying output. This verifies daemon functionality and registry connectivity.

questions.question: A system administrator notices Docker installation failed on a Linux server with the error 'package not found'. What is the most likely cause and solution?
options: The server lacks sufficient memory; add more RAM
The Docker repository wasn't added to the package manager sources
The server's firewall is blocking Docker installation
The user doesn't have sufficient disk space
questions.explanation: Most Linux distributions don't include Docker in their default repositories. The official Docker repository must be added to the package manager before installation can succeed.

questions.question: When would you choose to install Docker Engine (Community Edition) on a Linux VM instead of using Docker Desktop on your local machine?
options: When you need a graphical user interface for container management
For production deployments or when you need lightweight, headless container runtime
When you want to run both Linux and Windows containers
To get access to premium Docker features and support
questions.explanation: Docker Engine is ideal for servers and production environments where you need a lightweight, command-line-only container runtime without the GUI overhead and additional features of Docker Desktop.
